results.title: Theremin
results.brief_description: The theremin was invented in 1920 and is played by harnessing electricity. Though it’s most commonly associated with sci-fi, it’s first use was in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945).

constellations_primary.name: Good vibrations
constellations_primary.description: Since its invention, the humble theremin has been used in a number of different ways to evoke all sorts of strange sounds and moods.

results.description: The eerie sound accompanying the alien invasion in The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) is almost more iconic than the flying saucers themselves. Composer Bernard Herrmann created those other-worldly vibrations with duelling theremins, an instrument invented by Léon Theremin in 1920 that is played by harnessing electricity. Though the theremin is most commonly associated with science fiction, it was first used in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945). For a dream sequence designed by Surrealist artist Salvador Dali, composer Miklós Rózsa used the theremin’s strange reverberations to produce unease and psychological tension. The instrument has also been used in films like Ed Wood (1994), Mars Attacks (1996) and First Man (2018), along with TV shows and videogames.
description_for_label: The eerie sound accompanying the alien invasion in The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) is almost more iconic than the flying saucers themselves. Composer Bernard Herrmann created those other-worldly vibrations with duelling theremins, an instrument invented by Léon Theremin in 1920 that is played by harnessing electricity. Though the theremin is most commonly associated with science fiction, it was first used in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945). For a dream sequence designed by Surrealist artist Salvador Dali, composer Miklós Rózsa used the theremin’s strange reverberations to produce unease and psychological tension. The instrument has also been used in films like Ed Wood (1994), Mars Attacks (1996) and First Man (2018), along with TV shows and videogames.

results.title: Always a farmer
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Not just a farmer’s wife, Jenny Grigg, mother of four and business partner in all ways with her husband on their Mallee sheep and grain farm discovered a group of women who were to change Jenny’s life forever.
This story is dedicated to that network of women (PinG) who help and support other farming women in grains by providing inspiration and encouragement and a feeling of self-worth.

results.title: Hats in the Ring
results.brief_description: Focuses on the role of women in local government and contains a collection of interviews with women involved in local government, including two Lord Mayors, Sallyanne Atkinson of Brisbane and Lecki Ord of Melbourne, Janice Crozio, former NSW Minister for Local Government, Dawn Fraser, NSW Member of Parliament, and Senator Margaret Reynolds, Minister of Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Its aim is to encourage women to stand for.

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Just smile and shine
results.creator_credit: Anna Huynh, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Anna Huynh tells of how she learned the hard way the pitfalls of trying to fit in. Looking different to everyone else, she tried doing everything her peers were doing and it took her further away from herself. In being true to herself, she discovered the true friendship and, ultimately, her true self.

results.title: Running out of patience
results.brief_description: In October 1986, Victorian nurses began an historic strike action which was to last 50 days. This video is the nurses version of the dispute. Despite widespread condemnation mainly from the media, the nurses eventually won out for an appropriate career structure including significant pay increases. Actual strike footage together with nursing training films and old photographs explore vocational stereotypes and place the strike in the context of the current crisis in the health care system.

results.title: Artists in cyberculture
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions
results.brief_description: Artists record their work at the Third International Symposium on Electronic Art, Sydney, 1992. Through a series of interviews, performance, electronic theatre, this video looks at ways in which artists challenge the emerging technological realm known as “cyberculture”. It also examines issues such as gender, the body, the homogenisation of culture and the social and environmental implications of new technologies. Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions

Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.
